image.altText: A composite of a woman with long blonde hair, and a young person holding an Adidas sneaker.

items.synopsis: When Sarah Luke found out her personal details had been shared on the dark web, she never imagined it would lead to two US court actions and a million-dollar damages bill.

title.children: Sarah's data was stolen. Now she owes $US1.2m to Adidas and the US National Basketball Association

image.altText: Pilot sitting in the cockpit of a small plane.

items.synopsis: Former US Marine pilot Daniel Duggan speaks publicly for the first time from his prison cell as he fights extradition to the United States over allegations he trained Chinese military pilots more than a decade ago.

title.children: Australian 'Top Gun' pilot speaks publicly for the first time since his arrest for allegedly training Chinese military pilots

image.altText: A man wearing a tiger headdress and yellow robe

items.synopsis: Football fans wearing tiger headdresses, hair flowers and flowing yellow, blue and red flags have come from across Sydney to pump up the Colombian national team ahead of today's match.

title.children: 'Runs in our blood': Colombia fans promise passion ahead of Women's World Cup match against South Korea

image.altText: Stocks displayed on a screen at the ASX

items.synopsis: Investors are bracing for Australia's inflation data, US tech earnings and global central bank meetings. Barbie's box office opening boosts Mattel on Wall St. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX tipped to follow global stocks higher, Mattel shares rise after Barbie opening

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Home prices continue to defy expectations, rising despite 12 interest rate rises and forecasts of one or two more hikes ahead. There aren't as many homes for sale as usual, but enough people are competing for them to keep pushing prices higher nationally. So just who is buying them? ABC business reporter Nassim Khadem has found migrants, retirees and first home buyers relying on 'the bank of mum and dad' haven't been deterred by the recent market conditions. Take the Lindemans, for example — they are part of a group of property buyers using cash rather than taking out a home loan, so they're not directly affected by mortgage rate rises. "We're empty nesters looking to downsize… It's certainly a huge relief. And it's nice to get the property within the range we were sort of looking at," Thomas Lindeman says. Settlement data from PEXA shows there have been fewer buyers requiring a home loan, meaning that cash buyers — the majority of which were older Australians looking to downsize or retire — have increased as proportion of overall sales. "This speaks to the distribution effects of the interest rate changes that we've seen, because this group is largely unaffected by interest rates when they're making those decisions to move," PEXA chief economist Julie Toth says. You can read the full story below and catch The Business tonight from 8:45pm AEST on ABC News Channel and anytime on iView .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Who is buying property amid rising interest rates and house prices?

featuredLink.title: The Lindemans bought their new home at auction — and paid in cash. They're part of a growing trend

children.content: Home prices continue to defy expectations, rising despite 12 interest rate rises and forecasts of one or two more hikes ahead.
There aren't as many homes for sale as usual, but enough people are competing for them to keep pushing prices higher nationally.
So just who is buying them?
ABC business reporter
Nassim Khadem
has found migrants, retirees and first home buyers relying on 'the bank of mum and dad'
haven't been deterred by the recent market conditions.
Take the Lindemans, for example — they are part of a group of property buyers using cash rather than taking out a home loan, so they're not directly affected by mortgage rate rises.
"We're empty nesters looking to downsize… It's certainly a huge relief. And it's nice to get the property within the range we were sort of looking at," Thomas Lindeman says.
Thomas Lindeman and his wife recently purchased a smaller property at auction after selling their family home.
(ABC News: Simon Tucci)

Settlement data from PEXA shows there have been fewer buyers requiring a home loan, meaning that cash buyers — the majority of which were older Australians looking to downsize or retire — have increased as proportion of overall sales.

"This speaks to the distribution effects of the interest rate changes that we've seen, because this group is largely unaffected by interest rates when they're making those decisions to move," PEXA chief economist Julie Toth says.
You can read the full story below and catch
The Business
tonight from
8:45pm AEST
on
ABC News Channel
and
anytime on iView

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Vanguard has issued a response to ASIC bringing legal proceedings over allegations of greenwashing. The company says it self-identified and reported a breach in one of its product disclosure statements to the regulator back in 2021. "While the Fund was managed by Vanguard in alignment with the Index methodology, Vanguard identified that the descriptions of the exclusionary screens published by the Index provider and within Vanguard’s Product Disclosure Statement (PDS) were not sufficiently detailed," it says. "At the time, the description of the exclusionary screens did not provide a sufficiently detailed explanation that certain debt issuers lacking research coverage were still included in the benchmark. "As a result, it is possible the portfolio held exposure to certain securities that may not have been reasonably expected by investors." Vanguard says it moved quickly to inform investors and improve its PDS, and has fully cooperated with ASIC. "There was never any intention to mislead, but Vanguard recognises it has not lived up to the high standards it holds itself accountable to and apologises for the concern this matter may cause for our clients." In the two years since, Vanguard says it's appointed a head of ESG Product, added more resources to its disclosure and oversight teams, and enhanced its processes. As of December, Vanguard has paid nearly $40,000 in infringement notices issued by ASIC over alleged greenwashing.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Never any intention to mislead', says Vanguard

children.content: Vanguard
has issued a response to
ASIC
bringing legal proceedings over
allegations of greenwashing
The company says it self-identified and reported a breach in one of its product disclosure statements to the regulator back in 2021.

"While the Fund was managed by Vanguard in alignment with the Index methodology, Vanguard identified that the descriptions of the exclusionary screens published by the Index provider and within Vanguard’s Product Disclosure Statement (PDS) were not sufficiently detailed," it says.
"At the time, the description of the exclusionary screens did not provide a sufficiently detailed explanation that certain debt issuers lacking research coverage were still included in the benchmark.
"As a result, it is possible the portfolio held exposure to certain securities that may not have been reasonably expected by investors."
Vanguard says it moved quickly to inform investors and improve its PDS, and has fully cooperated with ASIC.

"There was never any intention to mislead, but Vanguard recognises it has not lived up to the high standards it holds itself accountable to and apologises for the concern this matter may cause for our clients."
In the two years since, Vanguard says it's appointed a head of ESG Product, added more resources to its disclosure and oversight teams, and enhanced its processes.
As of December, Vanguard has paid nearly $40,000 in infringement notices issued by ASIC over alleged greenwashing.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The corporate regulator ASIC has commenced legal action against Vanguard Investments Australia, seeking civil penalties. It's brought the case over allegations of greenwashing — ASIC says Vanguard engaged in misleading conduct by making claims about certain environmental, social and governance exclusionary screens applied to investments in a Vanguard fund. The regulator alleges that false statements were made in relation to Vanguard Ethically Conscious Global Aggregate Bond Index Fund and how the securities in the fund were screened according to certain ESG criteria. ASIC is arguing that ESG research was not conducted over a significant proportion of issuers of bonds in an index the fund was based on, and therefore the Vanguard fund itself. "We know that investors are increasingly seeking investment options that exclude certain industries, and investors need to be able to rely on investment screens to help them make these choices," ASIC deputy chair Sarah Court said. "In this case, Vanguard promised its investors and potential investors that the product would be screened to exclude bond issuers with significant business activities in certain industries, including fossil fuels. "We consider that the screening and research undertaken on behalf of Vanguard was far more limited than that being promised to investors, and we consider this constitutes another example of greenwashing." ASIC and the consumer watchdog ACCC have been cracking down on greenwashing activity in recent months. Vanguard has been contacted for comment.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASIC takes Vanguard to court over alleged greenwashing

children.content: The corporate regulator
ASIC has commenced legal action against Vanguard Investments Australia
, seeking civil penalties.
It's brought the case over
allegations of greenwashing
— ASIC says Vanguard engaged in misleading conduct by making claims about certain environmental, social and governance exclusionary screens applied to investments in a Vanguard fund.
The regulator alleges that false statements were made in relation to Vanguard Ethically Conscious Global Aggregate Bond Index Fund
and how the securities in the fund were screened according to certain ESG criteria.
ASIC is arguing that ESG research was not conducted over a significant proportion of issuers of bonds in an index the fund was based on, and therefore the Vanguard fund itself.

"We know that investors are increasingly seeking investment options that exclude certain industries, and investors need to be able to rely on investment screens to help them make these choices," ASIC deputy chair Sarah Court said.

"In this case, Vanguard promised its investors and potential investors that the product would be screened to exclude bond issuers with significant business activities in certain industries, including fossil fuels.

"We consider that the screening and research undertaken on behalf of Vanguard was far more limited than that being promised to investors, and we consider this constitutes another example of greenwashing."
ASIC and the consumer watchdog ACCC have been cracking down on greenwashing activity in recent months.
Vanguard has been contacted for comment.

image.altText: Black and white photo of large crowd of people, many squinting into the sun, aboard a boat, just visible.

items.synopsis: In 1975, Indonesia troops invaded Timor-Leste, targeting, among others, the Chinese Hakka ethnic minority. These people remember what the day was like.

title.children: Four decades ago soldiers killed their family and friends. Today they celebrate their own survival

image.altText: The inside of a warehouse showing stacks of soft plastics, with some closer up.

items.synopsis: The major supermarkets have started sending samples of soft plastics overseas to be recycled, as they deal with the legacy of thousands of tonnes of stockpiled plastics from the collapsed REDcycle scheme.

title.children: Thousands of tonnes of soft plastics could be sent offshore, as supermarkets look to restart local recycling program

image.altText: smiling older man looking at camera

items.synopsis: Good Samaritan Terry Bishop had been travelling to Brisbane on Friday to attend a family member's wedding. Family members say he was a man who would go out of his way to help anyone.

title.children: 'Absolutely devastated': Bruce Highway triple-fatal victim Terry Bishop had been travelling to family wedding

image.altText: Women wearing red soccer jerseys walking onto a green pitch

items.synopsis: Had Morocco qualified for the Women’s World Cup a decade ago, a player who wanted to wear the hijab during a game might have been forced to choose between faith and football.

title.children: Hijabs were only authorised by FIFA in 2014 — Nouhaila Benzina is the first to wear one at the Women's World Cup

image.altText: A composite photo of two women and two men.

items.synopsis: Live coverage of a police press conference in the wake of murder charges after a triple-fatal crash on the Sunshine Coast.

title.children: Man charged with murder after triple fatal Bruce Highway crash

image.altText: A German striker makes a phone call gesture with her hand as she receives congratulations for a goal.

items.synopsis: Alex Popp and the German team have made the biggest impression so far at the Women's World Cup — they may have plenty of bigger challenges to come, but a first title since 2007 could well be on the table, writes Kate O'Halloran.

title.children: Dominant Germany lay out impressive case for Women's World Cup favouritism

image.altText: Smoke rises over a town, turning the sky a brownish orange.

items.synopsis: Authorities say thousands of firefighters are battling to bring the flames under control after a heatwave swept across the region.

title.children: Wildfires in Algeria kill 34 people, including 10 soldiers

image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian looking serious.

items.synopsis: ICAC inspector Gail Furness SC has written to former treasurer Matt Kean to advise him of the investigation after he wrote a letter complaining about the former premier's treatment last month, the ABC understands.

title.children: ICAC chief to probe delay in Gladys Berejiklian report, possible maladministration

image.altText: A desk wall with a sign reading "Public health unit COVID-19. Contact tracing officer'. An out-of-focus figure sits at the desk.

items.synopsis: Third-party call centre workers contracted Victoria's health department were not properly screened, according to the state's information commissioner.

title.children: Privacy watchdog says Health Department failed to protect Victorians' data during COVID

image.altText: Wicks is standing in her place, holding a piece of paper and looking towards the Speaker (not in shot).

items.synopsis: The former federal MP for Robertson names herself at the centre of allegations about alleged abuse by a "NSW member of parliament spanning more than 5 years".

title.children: Liberal Party figure Lucy Wicks claims she received hundreds of 'abusive' texts from NSW MP

image.altText: A young women in suit with a laptop

items.synopsis: Australia is in dire need of highly skilled researchers in the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) sector, but many report being stranded in their home country, unable to do their work here due to visa delays.

title.children: Australia is desperate for engineers like Sara — but she can't enter the country

image.altText: Two men walk off a cricket field looking cold and wet.

items.synopsis: Andrew McDonald defends the captaincy of Pat Cummins after the Australian skipper was criticised for his tactics at Old Trafford.

title.children: 'Opinions that we respect and opinions that we don't': Australian coach hits out at former keeper over Cummins comments

image.altText: A man inside a man-made hole with stones around pointing at an ancient tomb with yellow sand and dirt around.

items.synopsis: Archaeologists find at least 125 tombs in a 2,000-year-old Roman cemetery discovered in Gaza last year, most with skeletons still largely intact, and two rare lead sarcophaguses.

title.children: Rare dolphin-adorned sarcophagus among tombs discovered at a Roman-era cemetery

image.altText: A blonde woman holds a black and white portrait of jane birkin in front of casked and pall bearers

items.synopsis: The actress, singer and inspiration for a famous handbag was farewelled by her daughters and French celebrities.

title.children: 'Jane Forever': Fans gather outside Paris funeral of singer and actress Jane Birkin

image.altText: A black and white image of one man holding another man's hair up.

items.synopsis: Trevor Francis, who made history as England's first player to be paid 1 million pounds, dies of a heart attack in Spain at the age of 69.

title.children: England football mourns the death of history-making star forward

image.altText: a man in a simple black jacket sits behind microphones

items.synopsis: China's economy is in serious trouble. The country's property sector, once a powerhouse of national economic growth, is in meltdown — and there are predictions of worse to come, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: China's economy is in serious trouble — and it's bad news for Australia

image.altText: Natalie Keley wears a blue shirt at Go Between Bridge, where her sister Teisha Keley was found dead

items.synopsis: Many would have passed by the tangled mess of tents, swags and junk that made up a homeless camp along a riverside walkway in Brisbane's CBD, but no-one realised they were walking past a dead body.

title.children: Teisha's death under a city bridge was deemed not suspicious. Then her sister started asking questions

image.altText: A woman with brown short hair sits behind a microphone

items.synopsis: Senior public servant Kathryn Campbell resigns from the Department of Defence after coming under heavy criticism for her role in the Robodebt scandal.

title.children: Senior public servant in Robodebt scheme resigns from Department of Defence

image.altText: A graphic of a chocolate bar, single chocolates, and Australian currency, 2023.

items.synopsis: Stock up when you see your favourite confectionery on special because market analysts say chocolate prices are set to keep rising on the back of poor weather and the war in Ukraine.

title.children: From La Niña to an El Niño threat, chocolate prices facing a stormy future

image.altText: A woman wearing a blue shirt and gloves kneels in the dirt next to a bucket as she reaches into a hole with a small tool

items.synopsis: More than eight decades after Australian soldiers were transferred from temporary graves on the Kokoda Track to a wartime cemetery, a chance discovery reveals the task was never quite completed.

title.children: Deep in the PNG jungle, a landowner was upgrading his property. Then he made an astounding discovery

image.altText: A woman takes off a blue mask.

items.synopsis: COVID-19 isn't considered a public health emergency any more. But with so much sickness going around, experts say we need to think about how we can protect others.

title.children: The COVID restrictions of the past are (mostly) gone. So what's the etiquette if you've got the sniffles?

image.altText: Protesters demonstrate following a parliament vote on a contested bill.

items.synopsis: The bill passed by a 64-0 vote after opposition politicians abandoned the Knesset plenum in protest.

title.children: Israel's parliament ratifies contested law limiting Supreme Court powers, sparking protests

image.altText: A woman stands in red smoke, shouting into a megaphone

items.synopsis: Defying threats from protesters and a plea from the United States, Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has forged ahead with a bill that could push his nation towards a constitutional crisis. Here's how it all unfolded.

title.children: Israel's wild 24 hours explained: Heart surgery, a controversial vote and a country on the brink

image.altText: Three black women footballers wearing national team uniforms during a major tournament

items.synopsis: Four years ago, a record 13-0 scoreline sparked concerns around an expanded tournament. But the group stage so far has proved the doubters wrong.

title.children: Jamaica, Haiti, South Africa — what the World Cup group stage says about football's new order

image.altText: Sam Kerr with a bandage on her left calf at a Matildas training session in Brisbane.

items.synopsis: The extent of Sam Kerr's injury remains a mystery after Matildas youngster Kyra Cooney-Cross caused a brief panic by mistakenly saying her teammate had torn her calf.

title.children: Matildas play down panic over Kerr injury after teammate's slip of the tongue

image.altText: A commercial fridge filled with Coca Cola and other soft drinks.

items.synopsis: In April, the nation's doctors called again for the introduction of a tax on sugar-sweetened drinks. They are not alone, but here's an insight into why it's still not happening, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: Why hasn't Australia got a sugar tax? A look inside the machine of a subtle, ruthless war

image.altText: A mother sits on a black leather couch with her arms around her two young children.

items.synopsis: This refugee mother has waited for more than a decade to be reunited with her older children. Learning she'll have to wait a few more years has been devastating.

title.children: 'I need my children': Susan has spent 11 years fighting to be reunited with her two older children
